p: Imaging, including CT and MRI scans, is helpful in the diagnosis. MRI is more sensitive, and 95% of patients in the California Encephalitis Project had abnormal MRI findings [ 68], but MRI findings may nevertheless be normal [ 62, 68]. Although temporal lobe involvement was present in 86% of patients, 59% had extra temporal lobe abnormalities either in association with temporal lobe abnormalities or in isolation [ 68]. T2-weighted images may demonstrate signal changes right at the onset, followed by diffusion-weighted changes visible 3 days after the onset of symptoms [ 62, 68]. Contrast enhancement in MRI becomes positive over a period of 4â€“90 days after the onset of symptoms. T1-weighted changes develop during the course of the illness and can be normal, high or low. Necrotic lesions develop later, at 2 weeks, after the onset of symptoms [ 62]. Neonatal MRI images differ from those of older children. The parietal lobes, occipital lobes and insula may be affected more frequently than the temporal lobes [ 62]. Diffuse white matter lesions occur in patients with relapse HSE [ 62].
